```assetjson
  "pxt.json": "{\n    \"name\": \"Coconut Chaos 1.6\",\n    \"description\": \"\",\n    \"dependencies\": {\n        \"device\": \"*\"\n    },\n    \"files\": [\n        \"main.blocks\",\n        \"main.ts\",\n        \"README.md\",\n        \"assets.json\",\n        \"images.g.jres\",\n        \"images.g.ts\"\n    ],\n    \"targetVersions\": {\n        \"branch\": \"v1.12.51\",\n        \"tag\": \"v1.12.51\",\n        \"commits\": \"https://github.com/microsoft/pxt-arcade/commits/eb9fd884260f64c934fb51355e36f8c76272b6b4\",\n        \"target\": \"1.12.51\",\n        \"pxt\": \"8.5.63\"\n    },\n    \"preferredEditor\": \"blocksprj\"\n}\n"
}
```

```typescript
let turtle = sprites.create(assets.image`turtleImage`, SpriteKind.Player)
scene.setBackgroundImage(assets.image`beachBackground`)
sprites.onOverlap(SpriteKind.Player, SpriteKind.Enemy, function (sprite, otherSprite) {
    music.play(music.melodyPlayable(music.baDing), music.PlaybackMode.UntilDone)
})
```

## Introduction @showdialog 
**Orange Belt Game Building Session**

In this tutorial, you will explore an activity similar to what you might find at the beginning of Code Ninjas' Orange Belt curriculum, which focuses on using coding skills learned in the White and Yellow belts to code with JavaScript in MakeCode Arcade.

Click **Ok** to get started! 

![Game Example](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-yb-ob/blob/master/images/coconut-chaos.gif?raw=true "Coconut Chaos project") 

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 
 
## Add Code Comments  

Start by preparing the coding area with a **code comment** to keep things organized. 

- :keyboard: On line 1 of the coding editor, type `// Initial set up` to create an area where we add code for the background, our player, and other starting bits.

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
// Initial set up
```

## Add a Background
All good games need a background.

- :tree: Open ``||scene:Scene||`` and drag ``||scene:set background image to||`` into the code editor on line 2. 
- :mouse pointer: Click the palette and select **beachBackground** from **My Assets**.

Click ▶ to see the background appear on screen!

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
// Initial set up
scene.setBackgroundImage(assets.image`beachBackground`)
```

## Create the Player sprite
Add a Player sprite to the game.

- :keyboard: Press **Enter** to create a blank line below the `setBackgroundImage` code.
- :paper plane: Open ``||sprites:Sprites||`` and drag ``||sprites:sprite (img) of kind (kind)|`` onto the blank line.
- :mouse pointer: Rename the **variable** by highlighting **mySprite** and replacing it with **turtle**.
- :mouse pointer: Click the palette, and select the **turtleImage** from **My Assets**. 
- :keyboard: On a new line, set the Player sprite's starting position by typing `turtle.setPosition(80, 110)`.

Click ▶ to see the sprite appear in the correct place on screen! 

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
// Initial set up
scene.setBackgroundImage(assets.image`beachBackground`)
let turtle = sprites.create(assets.image`turtleImage`, SpriteKind.Player)
turtle.setPosition(80, 110)
```

## Let's Move!
Now we need to be able to move our Player sprite!

- :keyboard: Use the code `controller.moveSprite()` with the Player sprite variable name as the **parameter** to move the Player with keyboard inputs (WASD/arrow keys).
- :keyboard: The Player sprite only needs to move left and right. Update the line of code with the vx and vy **parameters** like this: `(turtle, 200, 0)`.
- :keyboard: Use the code `turtle.setStayInScreen()` with the **parameter** set to `true` to prevent our Player from leaving the screen.

Try it out! The turtle is now able to move left and right, and unable to leave the screen.

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
// Initial set up
scene.setBackgroundImage(assets.image`beachBackground`)
let turtle = sprites.create(assets.image`turtleImage`, SpriteKind.Player)
turtle.setPosition(80, 110)
controller.moveSprite(turtle, 200, 0)
turtle.setStayInScreen(true)
```

## Crazy for Coconuts!
Now that the Player has been created, the next step is to create the falling coconuts.

- :keyboard: Add a comment for this section underneath the existing code: `// Coconut logic`.
- :paper plane: Drag ``||sprites:sprite (img) of kind (kind)|`` underneath the new comment. Rename the sprite **coconut** then click the palette to select the **coconutImage** from **My Assets**.
- :paper plane: Change the **Sprite Kind** from `Player` to `Food`. 


![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
// Coconut logic
let coconut = sprites.create(assets.image`coconutImage`, SpriteKind.Food)
```

## Position the Coconuts
Position the Food sprite in a random place along the top of the screen.

- :keyboard: To spawn a coconut in a random place along the top of the screen, use the code `coconut.setPosition()`.
- :keyboard: Use `randint(0, 160)` as the **x position** and `0` as the **y position**.
- :keyboard: To have the coconut move, randomize the right/left movement with `coconut.vx = randint(-50, 50)`.
- :keyboard: Use `coconut.setBounceOnWall()` with the **parameter** `true` to prevent the coconuts from leaving the screen.

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
// Coconut logic
let coconut = sprites.create(assets.image`coconutImage`, SpriteKind.Food)
coconut.setPosition(randint(0, 160), 0)
coconut.vx = randint(-50, 50)
coconut.setBounceOnWall(true)
```

## Infinite Coconuts!
So far, we only have one Food sprite spawning in our game! To fix this, we are going to call the code repeatedly using an **interval loop**.

- :keyboard: Add the code `game.onUpdateInterval(1500, function() { })` using the code completion tool for assistance. Be sure to use **1500** as the time parameter.
- :keyboard: Highlight then cut the 4 lines of code for the Food sprite, then paste it in between the interval loop's curly brackets `{}`.

The coconuts will now spawn every 1500 milliseconds (1.5 seconds)!

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
// Coconut logic
game.onUpdateInterval(1500, function () {
    let coconut = sprites.create(assets.image`coconutImage`, SpriteKind.Food)
    coconut.setPosition(randint(0, 160), 0)
    coconut.vx = randint(-50, 50)
    coconut.setBounceOnWall(true)
})
```

## Coconut Control, Part 1
Set up a nested loop that will control the Food sprites' movement.

- :keyboard: Below the interval loop, add a forever loop: `forever(function() { })` using the code completion tool for assistance.
- :keyboard: Inside the curly brackets `{ }` of the forever loop, add this for loop: `for(let sprite of sprites.allOfKind()) { }` with `SpriteKind.Food` as the parameter for the `allOfKind` function.

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
forever(function () {
    for (let sprite of sprites.allOfKind(SpriteKind.Food)) {

    }
})
``` 

## Coconut Control, Part 2
Use the nested loops to control the Food sprites' acceleration and to check their position on screen. 

- :keyboard: Indented inside the for loop, type `sprite.ay +=3` to use **y acceleration** to simulate gravity.
- :keyboard: Underneath, check if the Food sprite is touching the bottom of the screen by typing 
`if (sprite.y > 110) {  
  sprites.destroy(sprite)  
}`
- :keyboard: Then, use `info.changeScoreBy(-1)` inside the `if` **conditional** to reduce the score.

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
forever(function () {
    for (let sprite of sprites.allOfKind(SpriteKind.Food)) {
        sprite.ay += 3
        if (sprite.y > 110) {
            sprites.destroy(sprite)
            info.changeScoreBy(-1)
        }
    }
})
```

## Bouncy Coconuts
Make the Food sprites bounce when they hit the Player sprite.

- :paper plane: From ``||sprites:Sprites||`` drag a ``||sprites:run code on (sprite) of kind (kind) overlaps (otherSprite) of kind (otherKind)||`` onto a blank line.
- :keyboard: Change the second `SpriteKind.Player` to `SpriteKind.Food`.

Inside the curly brackets `{}` of the overlap event:

- :keyboard: Reset the Food sprite's y-acceleration: `otherSprite.ay = 0`
- :keyboard: Change the Food sprite's y-velocity: `otherSprite.vy = randint(-100,-80)`
- :keyboard: Increase the score: `info.changeScoreBy(2)`

Test the game to ensure everything is working as expected!

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo") 

```typescript
sprites.onOverlap(SpriteKind.Player, SpriteKind.Food, function (sprite, otherSprite) {
    otherSprite.ay = 0
    otherSprite.vy = randint(-100, -80)
    info.changeScoreBy(2)
})
```

## Finishing Touches!
The game is looking great! Let's add a couple final details.

- :keyboard: Under `// Initial set up` add code to start the game timer: `info.startCountdown(15)`.
- :keyboard: Underneath, add code to set the initial score to 0: `info.setScore(0)`.
- :keyboard: Inside the Player/Food overlap event, add ``||music:play toPlay playbackMode||`` to play a sound effect when the Food sprite bounces off the Player sprite.

Playtest your game, and continue working on it until everything works as expected. Customize the sprite images or add other code to provide game instructions, additional sound effects, or other Food sprites!

When you have finished, click **Done**. Then, follow your Code Sensei's guidance to create a shareable link that will let you play your game at home!

![Logo](https://github.com/Code-Ninjas-Home-Office/game-building-session-tutorials-2024/blob/master/images/CN-Logo.png?raw=true "CN Logo")
